text: I have to admit I'm not a Cancun kind of
guy it may be the crass commercialism
maybe it's because my aesthetic sense
recoils at the zona Hotel era the hotel
zone maybe it's just Senor frog or maybe
as the frugal traveler I'm just too poor
to enjoy what's increasingly a five-star
destination my weekend budget of $500
won't take me that far it in an
all-inclusive resort so when I visited
Cancun instead of actually staying in
Cancun I skipped a few minutes north to
Porto Juarez that's where I found the
via Playa Blanca a sweet
bed-and-breakfast run by Alejandro
Gutierrez and Orazio vias con comfy bed
yummy breakfast private balcony for $45
a night who needs Cancun proper just
down the street from the via Playa
Blanca was a beach not Playa Blanca as
you might expect but Playa Nino's this
was very much a family hangout maybe too
family-oriented for me I wasn't quite
ready for Cancun's main drag but I
wanted a little more glamour than Playa
ninos
so the next morning I walked to the port
of Puerto Juarez planning to catch a
ferry to isla mujeres a small island
circled with beaches I've been told to
seek out playa north day and there it
was right at the north end of the island
nice and lazy just how I like it
now most of these lounge chairs belong
to bars and restaurants and resorts and
if you want to sit down you'll have to
buy an overpriced drink but this spot
was completely ignored by waiters wonder
why
at last I got my chair working and then
well then I just sat and watched an kun
again from a safe distance but as I
pondered the water I knew something was
wrong
sure I could circle around Cancun easily
enough eating cheap tacos and avoiding
anything that smacked of gaudiness but
could I then tell people I'd really been
to Cancun that night I decided to face
my fears Coco Bongo the most mega of the
mega clubs in the hotel zone this was
exactly the kind of scene I can't deal
with hardly frugal but this is what the
kids come to Cancun for right and so I
paid at least it was open bar alas no
camcorders were allowed inside the club
but regular cameras were perfectly okay
Coco Bongo was no normal nightclub sure
people drank and danced on the bar but
the big attraction was the show a
non-stop ever mutating series of lip
synced performances that veered from
old-school crooners and Brazilian esque
dancers to gymnasts flamethrowers and of
course the routine inspired by The
Passion of the Christ
that weekend I spent two hundred ten
dollars and 37 cents and you know maybe
I am a Cancun kind of guy but I really
don't belong at Coco Bongo
